724268f-a.title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip
724268f-a.text:
Water Street, north side, west from but not including Pike Slip. The view is taken from the Manhattan Bridge. The side of the building shown on the right is part of clearance from bridge construction and is not a street. The opposite side of the bridge
is Pike Slip. Breadline of mendicant's is shown.
June 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
The same, from a different angle.
July 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
724268f-a.folder: Water Street & Pike Slip, Manhattan, NY

724271f-b.title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip
724271f-b.text:
472 to 478 Water Street (left to right), at, adjoining and east of the N.S. corner of Pike Slip. Also shown are 77 to 71 Pike Slip, north froE. and including Water, to and including Cherry Streets.
March 30, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A portion of the same, showing a closer view of Nos. 474-476.
March 30, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as view No. 1, at a later date. Note the clearance on the
N.E. corner of Pike Slip. and Cherry Street.
March 22, 1937.
9P. L. Sperr.

724249f.title: Manhattan: Water Street - Peck Slip
724249f.text:
Water Street, south across Peck Slip to Fulton Street. The towering 60 Wall Tower dominates the background and overshadows
this,the Fulton Fish Market locale.
1939
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
Neg. - dd i11gN
724249f.folder: Water Street & Peck Slip, Manhattan, NY

722530f-a.title: Manhattan: Peck Slip - Water Street
722530f-a.text:
11 Peck Slip, north side, west of Water Street, showing an old structure that is supposed to have been standing in 1725, on land owned by Johans Hardenbrooke. It is now the property of Wm. H. Scheel. For
further data see other views.
November 8, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
722530f-a.folder: Peck Slip & Water Street, Manhattan, NY

722531f-a.title: Manhattan: Peck Slip - Water Street
722531f-a.text:
11 to 5 Peck Slip, north side, west of Water Street. No. 11 (right) is believed to have been standing in 1725 on land owned by Johans Hardenbrooke. This and other pieces of property on Peck Slip passed to the Roosevelt family in 1755,and from whom this unit passed to the Scheel family; the present owner being Wm. H. Scheel, importer of varnish gums. No. 9, the adioining structure housed Ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith during his earlier days. North of the latter is a 3-story frame house, occupied by a junk shop, but formerly, the residence of Dr. Valentine of
Valentines Manual fame.
October 1937.
George D. Chinn.
722531f-a.folder: Peck Slip & Water Street, Manhattan, NY

722567f-b.title: Manhattan: Pike Slip - Water Street
722567f-b.text:
Pike Slip, east side, south from and including Water, to and inclndtmg South Street. The Manhattan Bridge is shown overhead, extending out over
the East iver to Brooklyn.
June 17, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same from a slightly different angle.
April 25sh,I939
P.L.Sperr,

724272f-a.title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip
724272f-a.text:
479-487 Water Street, south side, cast of Pike Slip. No. 479-481 is
a frame building.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 10.
724272f-a.folder: Water Street & Pike Slip, Manhattan, NY

724273f-a.title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip
724273f-a.text:
486-494 Water Street, north side, between Pike Slip and Rutgers Slip. Nos. 486-488 is a frame shack and wall enclosing a lumber yard. (Direction of Water Street is arbitrarily set to run east
and west).
April 16, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
The same, and showing a further view eastward to and including Rutgers Slip. Note the absence of No. 492-494 a 6-story tenement shown
in No. 1.
March 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
724273f-a.folder: Water Street & Pike Slip, Manhattan, NY
